question.title: Only the first JLabel generated in a for loop being displayed
question.body:
I'm learning Java and am trying to make a password manager with Swing and MigLayout; in this problem I'm trying to make a list of boxes within a JPanel with three labels: the 'domain name', the 'username', and the 'notes'. My current method generates each of the panels correctly (I know this as I have a coloured background), but it only shows the labels for the first box in the list. (Side note: I'm new to swing and generating a JPanel with JLabels and listeners to make a rudimentary panel-like button was just my first idea -- if you know a better way of doing this please let me know)

Main.list is an array list of objects of my Entry class, which for now just holds the username, password, etc. of each 'entry' (account), and the for loop seems to generate the panels correctly. Adding system.out dialogue to print the text that it's supposed to be adding shows it is indeed reading the data correctly, but only the labels for the first infoBox are shown.

Am I using JLabel or JPanel incorrectly? Is it an issue with how I'm calling the constructor, or the constructor itself? Is it my layout manager (I have no clue how MigLayout works)? I've tried re-writing this several times and all yield the same result.

I've included the Main class that UI.main is called from and the raw text of the input file, but I've not included the FileIn or FileOut classes since I've confirmed the data input works as intended from the system output afterwards and I don't want to include a load of code that isn't necessary.

answers.body:
The main issue is the use of MigLayout parameters.
If you expect to create a 3-column (one row) infoBox panel with those 3 labels, you may fix the MigLayout for this case, sizes can be defined in the second parameter (for column constraints), the value format is min:preferred:max , or the shortcut number! equivalent to number:number:number

private static MigLayout infoBoxLayout = new MigLayout(
    "wrap 3", // row constraints
    "[grow][grow][grow]", // columns constraints, can specify specific sizes eg: "[400!][700!][grow]",
    "" // cell constraints
);

In case you want a 3-row, full-width (one label by row), you may need something like this:

private static MigLayout infoBoxLayout = new MigLayout("wrap 1", "[grow]", "")

For reference, the MigLayout cheatsheet http://www.migcalendar.com/miglayout/mavensite/docs/cheatsheet.html

question_comments.body: Hello user, welcome, without having an image of what you need, it's impossible to help you, although I can give you some advice: if you don't know how it works, don't use it (or learn how to use it).
maybe a minimal reproducible example would have been better

new JPanel(infoBoxLayout) ← I don’t know much about MigLayout, but I know that using the same LayoutManager instance for multiple containers is not supported by any LayoutManager implementation in Java SE. The same is probably true for MigLayout.

I can't comment on what's actually wrong - but it's really odd to call a constructor when you only care about the side-effects of the constructor, not the newly-constructed instance. (I'd also note that infoBox is an unconventional name for a class in Java - I strongly encourage you to follow naming conventions.) I'd convert that constructor into a static method - that would be more idiomatic, and avoid creating pointless objects.
